body: WALTON - Minnie. Loving wife of the late Alex. Beloved mother of Larry and Carol. Mother-in-law to Jerome and Fern. Adored grandmother of Alex, Samantha, Andrew and Jeri. Services 10 AM today at Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY (Avenue M).
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WALTON, MINNIE

body: Some sports buffs have the feeling we were born on Feb. 29. That is to say, one year is automatically better than three others. For us, 2002 was the year, as will become perfectly clear by the end of May. NEW YORK, JAN. 8 -- Bud Selig's frantic attempt to eliminate the Minnesota team is further sullied by revelations that Selig accepted a loan from
title: Sports of The Times; A Personal Leap Year: Some Postcards From 2002

body: FOR Eric Drysdale, the mundane task of clearing out some clutter from his wife's grandmother's apartment opened up, almost literally, a new dimension. ''I came across an old stereoscopic camera, a 3-D viewer and tons of 3-D images of her grandparents from the late 40's,'' said Mr. Drysdale, 34, a writer for ''The Daily Show'' on Comedy Central.
title: 3-D Oohs and Aahs, the Old-School Way

body: Breezing along on gusts of stale air and perky inanities, ''Two Weeks Notice'' is a romantic comedy so vague and sadly undernourished that it makes one of Nora Ephron's low-cal strawberry sodas seem as tempting as a Philip Barry feast. As George Wade (Hugh Grant), a rich, piggy New York real estate developer, and Lucy Kelson (Sandra Bullock), the
title: FILM REVIEW; Is She an Ugly Duckling? No, She's a (Gasp!) Swan

body: Preparing for a possible transit strike on Monday, FleetBoston Financial has hired four buses to bring employees from the four other boroughs into Manhattan. The free transportation is not a perk to pamper high-paid executives; it is insurance that 200 lower-wage workers like bank tellers and security guards can get to the company's 23 Manhattan
title: THE TRANSIT SHOWDOWN: COMMUTERS; Car Pools, Hired Buses and E-Mail From Home

body: The gangland moniker of Abe Reles was Kid Twist. In 1941, the Murder Inc. member became an informer for the police and helped the Brooklyn prosecutor Bill O'Dwyer send Frank (Dasher) Abbandano and Harry (Pittsburgh Phil) Strauss to the electric chair. But before he could testify against Louis (Lepke) Buchalter or Benjamin (Bugsy) Siegel, Reles --
title: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 12-01-02: ON LANGUAGE; Defenestration

body: A man who had apparently fallen onto the tracks of the subway station at East 16th Street and Avenue U in Sheepshead Bay was killed early yesterday when a northbound Q train ran over him as it pulled into the stop, the police said. The man, who was not immediately identified, was believed to be in his 20's, the police said. He was wearing the pants
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Killed On Subway Tracks

body: Snow and bitter cold lurk on the horizon, but the Coney Island Polar Bear Club, which turns 100 this winter, does not have a home. It is not like club members to complain about the cold. These are people renowned for plunging into the Atlantic every Sunday from October through May, regardless of weather. But for the first time in recent memory, the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CONEY ISLAND; Lacking Fur, Chilly Dippers Would Like a Changing Shack

body: A private developer has proposed building two or three so-called big-box stores on Pier 40 in Greenwich Village, the same neighborhood that resoundingly rejected a Costco store just two years ago. This time, however, the superstores would be accompanied by a giant carrot for the community: a 15-acre sports park that would occupy the top level of
title: Big-Box Plan, but With Icing on Top

body: A second person was charged yesterday in the killing of a Ukrainian immigrant who was shot to death in Brooklyn last month as he tried to protect his wife from two armed robbers, the police said. The suspect, Naquasia Pollard, 19, was arrested and charged with first-degree murder in the death of the immigrant, Oleg Bosenko, a 38-year-old former
title: 2nd Arrest in Ukrainian Immigrant's Death

body: A two-time felon out on parole has been charged in the death of a Ukrainian immigrant who was shot to death in Brooklyn last month as he tried to protect his wife from a pair of armed robbers, the police said. The suspect, Joseph Johnson, 25, of Coney Island, was arrested late Thursday night and charged with the murder of Oleg Bosenko, a
title: Felon Accused of Killing Man Who Shielded Wife in Holdup

body: THE NAVIGATOR OF NEW YORK By Wayne Johnston 483 pages. Doubleday. $27.95 Piblocto is an Eskimo word for Arctic madness or strain, according to Wayne Johnston in his fifth novel, ''The Navigator of New York.'' There is piblocto to spare in this historical novel about explorers at the beginning of the 20th century and their race to reach the North
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; Traversing Wilderness, Frozen and of the Heart

body: WHAT'S the best way to set New Yorkers to bickering? Ask where to find the best slice of pizza in the city. No subject starts a battle faster -- not bagels or hot dogs or chopped liver, not even the primacy of the Rangers or the fastest route to J.F.K. Pizza, introduced to New York in 1905 by Gennaro Lombardi, who saw it as a way to use up the
title: Pizza 2002: The State Of the Slice

body: THE New York restaurant scene has been going strong since the 1800's. This month, museum exhibitions, books and even a new restaurant dining room take a big bite of the past. ''New York Eats Out,'' an exhibition that pays tribute to the city's long history of dining out, runs from Friday through March 1 at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue
title: FOOD STUFF: HISTORIC NEW YORK; At Some Famous Restaurants, It's Already Too Late to Call Ahead

body: Paul Kronenberg of Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, says he is trying hard to break out of ''this subway buff syndrome,'' one that has held him in its stubborn grip for at least 50 years now. But it cannot be easy, especially when he goes to sleep each night and rises each morning to see a motorman's cab from an old subway car bearing down on him from a
title: TUNNEL VISION; Taking the Train Home, Carefully, One Piece at a Time

body: New York's selection as America's entry in the global competition to hold the 2012 Summer Olympics won proud and enthusiastic toasts yesterday from city and state officials, from some of the town's movers and shakers and from a random sampling of ordinary people out on a golden autumn Marathon Sunday. Most foresaw huge new revenues from visitors, a
title: It's Pride Vs. Gridlock As City Looks To Olympics

body: It took crusty romantics like Tom Waits and his wife and longtime songwriting partner, Kathleen Brennan, to bring out the sympathetic side of the director and designer Robert Wilson. Their adaptation of Georg BÃ¼chner's strange and fractured 19th-century play ''Woyzeck,'' at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music through Nov. 16, is in
title: THEATER REVIEW; Woyzeck as a Normal Guy Who Gets Jealous

body: An ambitious Bloomberg administration plan to coordinate the city's so-called street furniture and, at long last, install public toilets is proving no easier than renovating a luxury penthouse for finicky clients. The sometimes-competing concerns of money, design and pedestrian flow were among the issues raised at a City Council hearing yesterday,
title: Critics Voice Opposition To City Plan On Toilets

body: ED (COOKIE) JARVIS was sipping a glass of water. A large man with a body shaped like a water balloon pinched at the top, Mr. Jarvis looked calm. ''I'm really hungry,'' he said. ''I had a brownie about 15 minutes ago.'' Mr. Jarvis, who weighs 409 pounds (''I'm like the spray,'' he said), was standing in the ballroom of the Atlantic Oceana nightclub
title: Big Eaters, Sure, But This Is Absurd

body: To the Editor: Re ''Golden Rules: In Pursuit of the Perfect City Sunset as Autumn Deepens'' (Oct. 13): Spectacular sunsets can often be seen from the elevated portion of the F train in Brooklyn as it heads toward Coney Island, especially at its highest point between the Smith-Ninth Street and Fourth Avenue elevated stations. Further along, and when
title: Fading Into History? Not So Fast; Subways and Sunsets Can Go Together

body: Bringing Back the Jump Q. I heard that the old parachute jump in Coney Island is going to reopen. Is that true? A. That's putting the bun before the hot dog, but the idea is being considered. Interest in the 262-foot parachute jump was renewed three weeks ago when the city's Economic Development Corporation announced plans to begin a $5 million
title: F.Y.I.

body: A 15-year-old girl was raped by another student in the basement of Sheepshead Bay High School yesterday afternoon, the police said. At about 2 p.m., she went with a 16-year-old she knew to the basement of the school, at 3000 Avenue X. He then raped her and ran away, the police said. The victim was taken to Coney Island Hospital for observation. The
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl, 15, Raped By Student, Police Say

body: A police officer who had just reported to her station house for roll call died of a gunshot wound to the head yesterday afternoon, in what the police said was apparently a suicide. The shooting occurred about 4 p.m. at the housing bureau station house at 2860 West 23rd Street in Coney Island, the police said. ''It was out of character,'' a police
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer's Death Believed a Suicide

body: To the Editor: Re ''Born on the Bayou and Barely Feeling Any Urge to Roam'' (front page, Sept. 30): While New York City is second to none in its acceptance of newcomers and its creation of a diaspora, it, like Louisiana, has a culture apart from the rest of the country that makes it hard to leave. Louisiana residents have their hunting clubs and
title: Brooklyn Homegirl

author: John Colapinto, a contributing editor to Rolling Stone, is the author of ''As Nature Made Him'' and the novel ''About the Author.''
body: It's easy to underestimate Gifford Miller, the 32-year-old speaker of the New York City Council. Riding the elevator on a visit to Con Ed headquarters on Irving Place, Miller stands dwarfed between the two security agents who escort him everywhere. On the short side, with a baby face framed by jug ears, he looks like a boy on a school field trip --
title: The Kid And His Council

title: Tunnel Vision; After a Century of Dreams, Still Envying the Sardine

body: A 9-year-old Brooklyn boy died yesterday after plunging three stories from a department store escalator to a floor crowded with shoppers, law enforcement officials said. The boy, Malcolm Lawrence of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was pronounced dead at 11:55 a.m., about 50 minutes after he spilled across the escalator's railing, according to officials.
title: Brooklyn Boy, 9, Is Killed In Fall From Mall Escalator

body: City health officials have recalled three South Asian-style dessert products that contain nuts, saying they do not come with a warning about their ingredients and could be dangerous to people with food allergies. The desserts, sold under the labels gajar halwa, besan burfee and Bukhara Sweets Mix, can be found in Brooklyn and Queens but could be
title: City Recalls Improperly Labeled Indian Sweets Containing Nuts

title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Fantasy Island

title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Greetings From Brooklyn, Ala.

title: Attacks Highlight Last Days of Campaign for Comptroller

body: Two weeks ago, Marina Bekkerman was bicycling with a group on Neptune Avenue in Coney Island when the driver of a double-parked van threw open his door as she passed and struck her in the back. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; To Bikers, an Open Door Is No Invitation

body: When hitting the road this summer, Cyd and Alec Daitsman have passed up hot spots like the Hamptons and Fire Island. But they do have minor-league ballparks, where the Daitsmans can indulge their summertime
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Fans Aren't Minor: They Root, Root, Root For the Home Team, Even on the Road

body: The surprising drop in median income in New York City that has puzzled demographers studying the results of the 2000 census appears to be traceable in large part to immigration, according to new census data that show income declines concentrated heavily in neighborhoods in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens that have become magnets for new arrivals.
title: Immigration Cut Into Income In New York, Census Finds

body: It's not quite the end of the city's rock world as we know it, but Manhattan's downtown music scene is shrinking again, even as Brooklyn's expands. The latest downtown casualty is Brownies, that East Village temple of alternative rock wedged into a dive of a bar. It closes its doors this weekend with the band Hot Socky holding forth. Brownies, on
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Rock Alternatives: A Music Scene Migrates to Brooklyn

body: ''My cummerbund is too tight'' and ''There's not enough vermouth in my martini'' are not usually heard at boxing matches. Officials announced the return of black-tie boxing to the Cipriani 42nd Street
title: BOXING; Promoters Try to Fill a Void By Finding Interesting Sites

body: Soft Landing for Owners After the Quilted Giraffe In the 1980's and early 90's, it was a restaurant whose name was on many a gastronome's tongue. It took a big chew out of their wallets, but top ratings by critics induced diners to part with their dollars. The restaurant was the Quilted Giraffe, whose owners, Barry and Susan Wine, opened it in 1975
title: FOLLOWING UP

title: Sports of The Times; Brooklyn Royalty Comes Home Again

body: BUILT in 1924, the Childs Restaurant building at West 21st Street and the Boardwalk was one of the last gasps of elegance for Coney Island, and its fireproof construction saved part of the neighborhood in a massive 1932 blaze. Now a preservation group says it wants the Brooklyn building to be made a landmark, an idea the current owner, whose family
title: Streetscapes/The Former Childs Restaurant in Coney Island; Colorful Terra Cotta and Stucco Homage to the Sea

body: THE SETTING -- A six-day trip by members of the Theater Historical Society of America to visit 24 defunct and operating movie theaters and playhouses in and around New York. A group of theater building enthusiasts, 202 strong, they came from across the country and from as far away as Canada, England and Australia. On a recent sunny Friday, they
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE -- BUZZ; Back When the Usher Was a Brooklyn Girl Named Barbra

body: An article in the special Favorites section on Tuesday about the F train of the New York subway misstated the elevated part of the train's route through Brooklyn to Coney Island. After emerging from underground after leaving the Carroll Street station, the train submerges again between the Seventh Avenue and Church Avenue stations. It does not run
title: Corrections

body: A 2-year-old Brooklyn girl who was reported missing on Thursday morning was reunited with her mother early yesterday, the police said. The child, Kenya Banks, had last been seen on Tuesday at 8 a.m. in the West 27th Street apartment in Coney Island where she lived with her mother, Elisa Owens, the police said. The mother had left her with a family
title: Missing Girl, 2, Is Reunited With Mother

body: The police said last night that they are looking for a 2-year-old girl and the woman her mother left her with on Tuesday. The girl, Kenya Banks, was left at 8 a.m. at her home on West 27th Street in Coney Island with Sharon Cooper, 32, who the police described as a family friend. When the girl's mother, Elisa Owens, came to pick up the girl, Ms.
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Search For Missing Girl

body: THAT'S him, there, the guy running around the field and jumping on top of the dugout between innings to dance the cha-cha slide with the ladies. After he finally gets a wave going, yelling so hard you wonder if he'll ever speak again, he takes off through the crowd, slapping high fives on a sea of raised hands. Two burly men watch him go. title: To Dance on a Dugout, A Guy's Gotta Eat

body: Nostalgia is nice, in part because of the exercise it gives your imagination. With nostalgia, you can almost believe that it is beautiful and sunny, not overcast and clammy, during a summer Sunday on Coney Island. You can almost not notice the man with the matted beard in the motorized wheelchair who is making circles in the middle of Surf Avenue
title: Tunnel Vision; A Trip to the Past on Rattan Seats (Mind Your Nylons!)

author: Randy Kennedy is a reporter for the Metro section of The Times who writes the Tunnel Vision column.
body: IN two years of constant riding and writing about the New York subway, I have noticed something interesting: whenever people talk about their favorite stretches, they rarely talk about the sub part. Instead, they sing love songs to the other half of the system, where trains don't run through tunnels but atop trestles, above the streets, rattling
title: Trips; The F Train Rises

body: What with a looming strike, owners requiring emergency loans to pay the exorbitant salaries they had promised, and an All-Star Game that ended in a tie and a nation of outraged fans, Major League Baseball's image is taking a beating these days. But a weekend tour of the city's professional ballparks found that how you feel about the summer game
title: If the Baseball Players Walk, Not Everyone Will Be Riled

author: Michael Shapiro's next book, ''The Last Good Season: Brooklyn, the Dodgers and Their Final Pennant Race Together,'' is due out next year.
body: I was 4 years old when the Dodgers left Brooklyn, but unlike the team, I stayed. I never went to Ebbets Field. I never even saw it. I lived in Brooklyn until I was 21 and when I, too, finally left, I did so still believing that had the Dodgers not abandoned the borough for Los Angeles, Brooklyn would have been altogether different, not the flat,
title: MY BROOKLYN; The Team That's Filling the Void the Dodgers Left Behind

body: THE best moment is swooping south on the F.D.R. Drive, just before the Manhattan Bridge, when the highway elevates again and it is like you are in a little airplane taking off. The view unfolds just over the silver hood: the downtown skyline, the East River bridges, Governors Island, the harbor. It's best at sunset, of course, when the piers in
title: No Particular Place to Go

body: NEIL SIMON grew up in the Bronx, but it is Brighton Beach that he brought to the stage and screen when he recalled his 1930's boyhood in ''Brighton Beach Memoirs.'' The first act opens in ''a wooden frame house, not too far from the beach. It is a lower-middle-income area inhabited mostly by Jews, Irish and Germans.'' Today's gawky Eugene Jerome,
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Brighton Beach; Magnet for Immigrants, Moving Upscale

body: Nathan's Hot Whale Q. I heard that the carcass of a whale was once on display in Coney Island. Why? A. It was indeed, and it was put there to entice people to eat. In 1954, Nathan Handwerker, founder of Nathan's Famous, the hot dog emporium on the Boardwalk, was vacationing in Miami Beach and had left the store under the watch of his son, Murray.
title: F.Y.I.

title: ON THE TOWN; From New Orleans To 52nd Street

body: More than half of the teaching hospitals inspected by the state Health Department have violated state laws meant to ensure that medical residents are not exhausted when caring for patients, the department said yesterday. Thirty of the 54 hospitals in violation were in New York City. Since November 2001, 82 teaching hospitals were inspected to see
title: State Says Many Hospitals Violate Laws on Work Hours

body: There were six wooden boxes for the seven members of the Nadeem family. The youngest, Zainab, who in life clung to her mother's bosom, as 9-month-old infants do, shared a simple pine coffin with her in death. On Coney Island Avenue, in rows ten deep, people who knew the Nadeems and hundreds more who did not mourned a man, a woman and their five
title: In Rows 10 Deep, Brooklyn Mourns a Family of Seven

body: The family of seven that perished together in a blaze in their Brooklyn apartment will be buried together in Pakistan after a funeral service that is expected to draw hundreds of mourners to a Coney Island Avenue mosque today. Yesterday, relatives and friends faced the grim task of arranging funerals for the family, Mohammad and Yasmeen Nadeem and
title: Family Killed in Fire Will Be Buried in Pakistan

body: Joe LaBarbara's infatuation with the Cyclone roller coaster in Coney Island began three years ago with the stories his father and grandfather told him of their own childhood rides. But Joe, now 11, was too short to go on the roller coaster and could only look at the ride through a chain link fence. He was still too short last year, but his father
title: Scaring the Daylights Out of Riders for 75 Years

body: Residents of Borough Park, Brooklyn, did not seem particularly worried yesterday by the F.B.I.'s warning on Friday that terrorists might use fuel tanker trucks for attacks on synagogues and Jewish schools. But they did express alarm about a Queens rabbi who responded to the new threat by saying he would resume his plan to bring armed patrols to
title: After F.B.I. Warning, Rabbi Renews Call for Armed Patrols

body: A Brooklyn woman was shot to death and her son was wounded Thursday night when a group of men knocked at their apartment door and then opened fire, the authorities said yesterday. title: Woman Fatally Shot At Apartment Door

body: The Mermaid Parade in Coney Island is one of New York City's bawdiest, an annual rite of summer, artistic freedom and scantily clad bodies. When this year's parade is held on Saturday, it may highlight a delicate question of personal expression and test women's rights to expose themselves. That is because of a lawsuit filed yesterday by Amy
title: A Parade of Fins and Skin Tests How Little Cover Is Legal

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council agreed last night on a budget that would close New York City's worst deficit in decades by going into debt, cutting many city services, suspending recycling of jars and bottles and raising the tax on cigarettes. Both sides expressed relief that they had reached an amicable accord on closing a nearly
title: NEW YORK CITY BUDGET: THE DEAL; Bloomberg and Council Agree On Budget to Close Big Deficit

body: TWO freshly minted Brooklyn Cyclones, members of this Class A baseball team that is more or less a wisp -- less would be the key word here -- of the late, loved and lamented Dodgers, were in this kaleidoscopic part of the universe for the first time yesterday, and feeling their way. One, a 22-year-old pitcher named Eric Templet, is from Gonzalez,
title: Sports of The Times; Call It Dodgers Lite, But Brooklyn Loves It

body: A rabbi from Queens who had planned to bring armed citizen patrols to protect Jewish neighborhoods in Brooklyn last night suspended the patrols ''until further notice'' because of opposition from residents and community leaders. A message on an answering machine set up by the rabbi, Yakove Lloyd, cited the ''overwhelmingly negative response by the
title: Rabbi Halts Plan to Bring Armed Patrol To Brooklyn

body: Tales of Coney Island's rebirth come around as often as a carousel. But this summer, a sense of impending progress is clinging to the salty air. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CONEY ISLAND; The Nickel Empire Longs To Recapture Its Seedy Glory

body: Where is Koko the Killer Klown? title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CONEY ISLAND; Island Love Story: Missing Klown Meets His Match, Bug Lady Ecstatic

title: Harlem Neighborhood Competes For a Stretch of Riverfront Turf

body: THE moment school let out for the summer, I always knew this: there wasn't a chance in the world it would ever start again. My preteenage mind simply could not contemplate the passage of 10 entire weeks. And so, with the world as I knew it permanently safe from fish sticks, protractors and the need to answer in complete sentences, everything under
title: The Lure of the Scare

title: BASEBALL: MINOR LEAGUE NOTEBOOK; Johnson at Ease Moving From Coach to Manager

body: I FIRST came to New York City when I was a child, 9 or 10, on a morning train from Boston, with my great-aunts Ruth and Grace. It was just before Christmas and snowing a little. title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW; On the Sidewalks of New York

body: Randolph Maddix, a schizophrenic who lived at a private home for the mentally ill in Brooklyn, was often left alone to suffer seizures, his body crumpling to the floor of his squalid room. title: For Mentally Ill, Death and Misery

body: Alan Dale, the Brooklyn-born baritone who crooned his way to popularity in the late 1940's and the 1950's with hits like ''Oh, Marie'' and ''Cherry Pink (and Apple Blossom White),'' died on Saturday at a hospital in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. title: Alan Dale, 73, a Crooner Popular in the 40's and 50's

body: New Yorkers are, to some extent, in a period of denial now. Which is understandable. title: The Calm Before The Cuts

title: Fiscal View From Mayor: Don't Panic, But Worry

body: On the westerly point of Coney Island is a spit of land known as Nortons Point. On that sliver of rock are a cottage and a lighthouse with peeling paint that are defended by a wizened old man who prefers the roar of the tide to the ring of the phone. The old man is Frank Schubert, 85, the last civilian lighthouse keeper in the country, and until a
title: So, It's a Lighthouse. Now Leave Me Alone.

body: The filmmaker Morris Engel, at 83 somewhat stooped with age, still living in the faded apartment on Central Park West he shared with his wife, the photographer Ruth Orkin, has no regrets. Long ago, in 1953, he made a dramatic film called ''Little Fugitive'' with Orkin and a friend, Ray Ashley. Shot in black-and-white in a pure, documentary style
title: A Filmmaker Who Valued Art More Than Fame

body: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. DANIEL O'CALLAGHAN Always at the Ready Summer and winter, morning, noon and night, Lt. Daniel O'Callaghan wore his thick black bunker pants around the Ladder Company 4 firehouse in Midtown Manhattan. ''It would be 102 degrees out, and he'd be wearing his
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; Blunt Talker, Devoted Aunt, Russian migr, Young but Wise Man

body: WEARING the look of an expectant father, Joe Winters worked the hallway of the Huntington Hilton, shaking hands and welcoming fight fans as if they were relatives headed for the maternity ward. It's not that pro boxing is new to Long Island, but the Friday night fight card promoted by Mr. Winters was billed as the rebirth of professional boxing
title: Friday Night Fights Return to the Island

body: TUCKED into a booth at Ben's Kosher Delicatessen in Baldwin, Don Lerman of Levittown gripped a knife in his right hand, quickly slicing baseball-size matzo balls into quarters like apples and shoveling one after the other into his mouth with his left. His fingers quivered. Crumbs dribbled down his chin and stuck in his beard. He didn't pause until
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL; Champion Overeaters, and Proud of It

body: With spring training scheduled to start in less than three weeks, David Cone said yesterday that he had not received any formal offers to pitch this season. ''I'm just throwing, working out on my own and waiting for an opportunity,'' said Cone, 39, who pitched last season for the Boston Red Sox, going 9-7 with a 4.31 earned run average in 25
title: PLUS: BASEBALL; Cone Still Waits For an Offer

author: E-mail: ernash@nytimes.com
body: Monument to the Slum Q. I'm told that New York's first tenement building is still standing. Where is it? A. The first building in New York constructed specifically as a tenement is at 65 Mott Street, near Pell Street, Tyler Anbinder writes in ''Five Points'' (Free Press, 2001), his history of the notorious 19th-century slum in Lower Manhattan. Mr.
title: F.Y.I.

body: HERE in Point Guard City, the buzz is about the smaller guys who handle the ball. Is Jason Kidd accurate enough? Is Stephon Marbury fitting in? Can Jason Williams be a star in the pros? In the town where every jaywalker is a point guard waiting to be discovered, the Knicks have three point guards but not much buzz. Oh, the Knicks did win a game
title: Sports of The Times; Marbury Is Better Off Elsewhere

body: To the Editor: Marsha Ackermann's logic in ''Stormy Weather and the Pleasures of Humility'' (Op-Ed, Jan. 8) is refreshing to read, but nothing new to me and my fellow members of the Coney Island Polar Bear Club. Weather is always with us; it's not news that it is cold in the winter and hot in the summer. Yes, the modern response is to ''overheat
title: A Winter Pleasure That's Not for Wimps

body: STREICHER-Blanche. Sister of Shirley Horowitz. Aunt of Bobbie and Roberta. Great-aunt of Erika, Tara and Rebecca. A person who loved independence, humor and chocolate ice cream. Love to you. Services Wednesday, 1 PM, at ''Weinstein - Garlick - Kirschenbaum Chapels,'' 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

body: Lincoln of Brooklyn rallied from a 14-point halftime deficit to top its Coney Island rival Grady, 62-59, in overtime yesterday despite the 4-for-27 shooting by guard Sebastian Telfair. title: PLUS: HIGH SCHOOLS; Coach Reinstated After Suspension

body: For years, the needy have come knocking on the door of Robin Alamilla and her husband, Kent Smith. Ms. Alamilla, 44, and Mr. Smith, 49, have been married for 26 years. Both are deacons at the Victory International Christian Fellowship church in Coney Island, where they live. For the last four years, the couple have led an outreach program called My
title: The Neediest Cases; A Couple Used to Helping Get a Helping Hand
